item.title: Comparing the Basics of Go and Python for New Programmers -- Part 2
item.description: Part One of this series comparing Go and Python can be found here. In Part One, I covered some of the differences between Python and Go when it comes to packaging and looping. This time, I want to cover a (slightly?) more advanced topic: blocking vs. non-blocking HTTP calls. To do this, we’ll write the same application in both Python and Go. This tiny demo application will retrieve the names of the original 150 Pokemon from a public API.

item.title: Comparing the Basics of Go and Python for New Programmers -- Part 1
item.description: I’m not trying to start a flame war, I swear. So let’s start off with this: if you’re already fluent in either Python or Go, this blog post isn’t meant to change your mind. Instead, it aims to compare some fundamental operations in each language and talk about how I feel about them. This is only Part 1. If it’s well-received, I’ll write more. If it’s not, I won’t. The title of this post includes the words for New Programmers, but it does expect the reader to have at least a passing familiarity with programming – or at least be able to understand pseudo-code.
